channel.title: TI-Calc Programming
channel.description:
I'm starting TI-Calculator threads now for mainly the 83-84 versions. I just want to get back to programming BASIC and making complex calculator programs again.
To start off I want to ask all of you who program or have ever used a program on a TI-Calc:
What is/are the most advanced/complex things you can program/have heard of/or seen?

item.title: TI-Calc Programming
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:8, topic:518477”]I don’t really know how to get full acces to the screen on my TI-84+ but here’s the program I made to calculate the points of a parabola that touch the x-line. (No idea how to say it properly in English since we follow Math in Dutch…)
And idk if this is what you meant by the BASIC language but ok…
Form: ax² + bx + c = 0

Input "A:",A Input "B:",B Input "C:",C (B)^2 - 4*A*C -> D Disp "DISCRIMINANT:",D If D<0 Then Disp "NO SOLUTIONS" End If D=0 Then Disp "OPL:", -B/(2*A) End If D>0 Then (-B + sqr(D)) / (4*A) -> X (-B - sqr(D)) / (4*A) -> Y Disp "OPL1:",X Disp "OPL2:",Y End[/quote]

TI calculators use a subset of the BASIC language for its programs. I’m not sure if this applies up the NSpire or not. I know the 89 doesn’t seem to use as verbose of a language as the earlier TI series.

Read full topic

item.title: TI-Calc Programming
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

I don’t really know how to get full acces to the screen on my TI-84+ but here’s the program I made to calculate the points of a parabola that touch the x-line. (No idea how to say it properly in English since we follow Math in Dutch…)
And idk if this is what you meant by the BASIC language but ok…
Form: ax² + bx + c = 0

Input "A:",A Input "B:",B Input "C:",C (B)^2 - 4*A*C -> D Disp "DISCRIMINANT:",D If D<0 Then Disp "NO SOLUTIONS" End If D=0 Then Disp "OPL:", -B/(2*A) End If D>0 Then (-B + sqr(D)) / (4*A) -> X (-B - sqr(D)) / (4*A) -> Y Disp "OPL1:",X Disp "OPL2:",Y End

Read full topic

item.title: TI-Calc Programming
item.dc:creator: @Togasa Togasa
item.description:
@Togasa wrote:

Ok so I just need someone with a program or the ‘want of’ a program so we can possibly start making it here.
Or if you, or anyone else, already have programs and want to see if they can be simplified or enhanced.
I haven’t been programming any of the above languages for atleast a year now and the worst part is I lost my TI-84+ SE anyways but that doesn’t mean I can’t help out as much as I can

Read full topic

item.title: TI-Calc Programming
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I programmed them by hand, other than the ones my professor provided in linear algebra (those were inserted via TI-connection). Most of my programs are gone now, due to multiple memory failures on the 83. No big deal, they weren’t hard to write.

The cube program had one for actually drawing and handling the rotation of the cube points, plus taking in key input. I needed a separate program for actually rotating each quad and I forget what the third was for. I might have separated drawing out of the main program, too. Not sure.

Read full topic

item.title: TI-Calc Programming
item.dc:creator: @Togasa Togasa
item.description:
@Togasa wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:4, topic:518477”]I have both a TI-83 and TI-89 (just bought the 89 a few weeks ago). My linear algebra professor programmed a series of functions for the 89 that perform a guass-jordan elimination algorithm on matrices in a custom F4 number field, which was pretty cool. I programmed something that did the same thing in C, but it would have been quite a pain in the ass to do it on the 89. Future project, most likely.

Uh, in geometry class I saw someone program a solver for SSS, SSA, etc triangles. I’ve programmed tons of things, ranging from area programs to the quadratic formula. These things are really handy on standardized tests! I programmed a simple 3D wireframed cube renderer that would rotate when you tapped the arrow keys (that was fun, I think it took 3 separate programs to pull off). I wrote one for filling a table full of RS level/experiences for various xp analyses in the past. Most recent one was a quick newton’s method solver. Meh, plenty of programs that I don’t remember anymore.[/quote]
Very nice to get a comment on my thread…especially from you but uhm quick question, do you copy the programs from the internet or from other people OR are you actually quite fluent in BASIC or ASM( ?
Also I see you mostly involve yourself with Math/Educational programs…not bad

I specialize much more in TI-83/84 models, so would you mind telling me any, and all, programs you have on your TI-84?
And can you also elaborate on how the cube program took 3 programs etc.
Thanks for commenting.

Read full topic

item.title: TI-Calc Programming
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I have both a TI-83 and TI-89 (just bought the 89 a few weeks ago). My linear algebra professor programmed a series of functions for the 89 that perform a guass-jordan elimination algorithm on matrices in a custom F4 number field, which was pretty cool. I programmed something that did the same thing in C, but it would have been quite a pain in the ass to do it on the 89. Future project, most likely.

Uh, in geometry class I saw someone program a solver for SSS, SSA, etc triangles. I’ve programmed tons of things, ranging from area programs to the quadratic formula. These things are really handy on standardized tests! I programmed a simple 3D wireframed cube renderer that would rotate when you tapped the arrow keys (that was fun, I think it took 3 separate programs to pull off). I wrote one for filling a table full of RS level/experiences for various xp analyses in the past. Most recent one was a quick newton’s method solver. Meh, plenty of programs that I don’t remember anymore.

Read full topic

item.title: TI-Calc Programming
item.dc:creator: @GNUd00d GNUd00d
item.description:
@GNUd00d wrote:

Ever since I was a kid I’ve wanted to know how to program my old ti-83
The most compilcated things ive seen are games like pacman, and simplistic vert based modeling producers. If gcc was possible then id be all over it, but seeing as how I dont think it even has basic, id just say to give up on anything ‘cool’

Read full topic
